title: Love Island's Cynthia Taylu opens up about the one thing that makes her feel 'vulnerable'
text:
Love Island Australia's Cynthia Taylu has spoken candidly about the one thing that makes her feel 'vulnerable'.

In an editorial for Ascension Magazine in April 2017, the 23-year-old newfound reality star revealed she often feels insecure about her natural hair.

'The act of leaving my hair out leaves me feeling vulnerable - it's letting the world know who I really am, and stripping off the layers is confronting,' she confessed.

'The act of leaving my hair out leaves me feeling vulnerable': Love Island Australia's Cynthia Taylu has revealed she often feels insecure about her natural hair

When she entered the Love Island villa in Fiji on Monday, Cynthia was seen arriving with long dark brown tresses that is believed to be a wig.

And it's unlikely she'll give her co-stars or the show's fans a glimpse at her natural hair while appearing on the show.

Originally hailing from Liberia in West Africa, Cynthia admitted the natural texture of her hair has always been something she's struggled with.

Wigging out: When she entered the Love Island villa in Fiji on Monday, Cynthia was seen arriving with long dark brown tresses that is believed to be a wig

Embracing her roots: Originally hailing from Liberia in West Africa, Cynthia admitted the natural texture of her hair has always been something she's struggled with

'Growing up in Australia, I always envied my Caucasian friends' hair - the texture, the length, and the ease of maintaining their hair,' she added.

Cynthia said she started wearing hair extensions in high school, and she hasn't really looked back since.

Although she sometimes wears her hair natural, she said people's fascination with it makes her reconsider.

Faux mane: It's unlikely she'll give her co-stars or the show's fans a glimpse at her natural hair while appearing on the show

According to Cynthia, wearing weaves and hair extensions gives her an 'extra boost of confidence'.

She said a major issue is the fact Australia doesn't cater to people with African hair.

'The main problem has been never knowing what to do with my hair. Hair salons aren't helpful because none of the stylists know what to do with my hair; supermarkets don't stock products for my hair texture,' she wrote.
description: Love Island's Cynthia Taylu has spoken candidly about the one thing that makes her feel 'vulnerable'.
authors: Demeter Stamell For Daily Mail Australia
